ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of intellectual challenge of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the workload of this course was:

narratives.question_text: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
comments: Learned how to read works by Milton, how to analyze works like Paradise Lost, how to form arguments and perspectives for literary purpose, how to read carefully and well.
I had the chance to learn about the life of John Milton and read some of his great works!
Ability to close-read; knowledge of Milton's work alongside the socio-political and cultural atmosphere of the poet's period; knowledge of William Blake.

I was able to embark on a in-depth and wonderful exploration of Milton and Paradise Lost. I was able to develop my skills of literary criticism, writing, and interpretation. I was introduced to a text that will resonate with me for years, if not decades, to come.
close reading was heavily emphasized and helped me to grow as a writer
I learned to closely read and analyze Paradise Lost and gained much fascinating insight.
Excellent analysis of Milton's Seminal works

narratives.question_text: What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
comments: I loved the discussion-like environment of the class, especially with such a dense book like Paradise Lost. It made my understanding and enjoyment of the course as high as it was. Professor Rogers also presents very intriguing and essential questions and perspectives to the discussion, which I really liked.
The reading was fun, but discussions could be a bit slow at times

Having the course on Zoom was a bit difficult, but otherwise the course was amazing! Ben and Professor Rogers are both brilliant, incredibly helpful in office hours, and keep seminar conversation going quite naturally. I enjoyed having the lectures to supplement the readings.
The course was wonderful. The professor was very engaging and excited for the course. The students were also very engaged and our discussions were always fascinating.
the discussion responses are kind of annoying but they also count as credit as long as you do them so not too bad

The course's engaging conversations make its great strength.  However, at one hour per discussion, it seems a bit short.  I think if they extend it to the regular hour and fifteen minutes, the conversations would flourish even better.
Lectures and discussions were amazing!
instructor's analysis was great

narratives.question_text: Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
comments: I would! As a student that does more STEM than humanities, I still found this class incredibly welcoming of all levels. Simply put, come as you are and your opinion is accepted!
Yes!  It's a great chance to learn about a polarizing writer whose legacy lives on throughout English literature today.
Absolutely! The course is a very accessible writing course while still allowing for intellectual growth and curiosity.
Yes. I learned a lot from this course and had a wonderful experience. I was sad for the course to end!
yes! john rogers is amazing and ben (the TA) was fantastic as well. super easy renaissance credit for the English major

Absolutely. I signed up for this class entirely out of necessity, but I could not be happier with the way things turned out. Prof. Rogers is very kind and helpful. His talks are easily digestible and incredibly fascinating. He also does a great job of leveling with students who are unfamiliar with classic literature. Take this class: if nothing else just to have some fun conversations with Rogers and explore some literature that is very weird, but also beautiful and captivating.
Definitely! Class with Professor rogers is always enjoyable.
Yes, if you want to learn about Milton, particularly Paradise Lost, its a good motivator with good commentary.

narratives.question_text: How will you use the knowledge and skills you learned in this course in your future endeavors?
comments: I really like Professor Rogers' approach to presenting and analyzing Milton's work. I feel more motivated to read works like Paradise Lost in the future because of it. It takes the pressure off of someone like me who isn't the best at literature. He showed me that I can enjoy reading old works and erased the stereotype of what can be seen as "boring". Incredibly thankful for the skills and knowledge he has given me!
I've left with a much deeper appreciation for Renaissance English poetry and an understanding of the richness in Milton's work.
I will use my close-reading and macro-analysis skills in working with texts and engaging with art in the future.
I will use these insights throughout my future explorations of literature, philosophy, religion, society, and human life.
This course was great at helping me understand better how to write a good paper.  I will apply what I learned to writing papers in future English classes.
Reading, analyzing, and writing skills will all be useful.
Analysis of Milton
